title: Model who bit woman sacks lawyer who said she looked ‘a million dollars’
text:
The actress bit a woman and pulled clumps out of her hair after getting involved in a ‘scrum’ on a train back from the races (Picture: Hyde News)

A model who bit a woman during a frenzied ‘scrum’ on her way home from a day at the races sacked her barrister after he said she ‘looked a million dollars’.

Eliza Peereboom, 23, was found guilty of biting the leg of Gabriella Marabet, 25, on a train from Newbury racecourse in Berkshire in August last year.

Peereboom has previous form, having bitten a police officer when she was 15.

Her sentencing at Reading Crown Court was postponed yesterday after she fired her defence lawyer and refused to speak with him.

Barrister Thomas Quinton said she ‘looked a million dollars’ and referenced the fact his client bought clothes from Primark and owned £2 sunglasses.

The fracas happened on a train carrying revellers home from Newbury racecourse where they had been dancing and drinking amid mid-summer celebrations (Picture: Hyde News & Pictures)

He told the court: ‘Today she is dressed like a million dollars.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘She is doing the best she can do to feel some value.

‘That has been her focus.

‘She informs me that her sunglasses are actually worth £2 and she shops in Primark.’

After a pause in proceedings to take instructions, Mr Quinton returned to court and said his client was no longer speaking to him.

The court was attempting to sentence Peereboom, who caused scarring to Ms Marabet when she bit her above the knee.

Ms Marabet told the court: ‘I had drunk around a bottle of Prosecco and three gin and tonics at the Newbury races with my family and friends but I was tired after a long day of dancing and chatting and slept on the train ride to Reading station where we were set to change for Oxford.

‘I went to swerve around a commotion in the alley when my hair was violently pulled forwards from the chair.

‘I kicked out and my leg was grabbed by the same girl who had my hair.

‘I was bitten just above the knee which felt like for ages but it was about 15 seconds long.

‘I screamed and was escorted off the train and she was kept on it.’

Ms Marabet added: ‘I had a bite mark and a sore head from where my hair was pulled.

‘I went to the doctors and I had to receive a Tetanus jab once a month for three months and a course of antibiotics.

‘I have a scar now. I have just got back from holiday and it looks worse now as the skin around it is darker.’

Peereboom left the stranger with a permanent scar and needed three months of Tetanus injections (Picture: Hyde News & Pictures).

The court heard that as well as the difficulties with the lawyer, Peereboom’s living situation would make it hard to complete unpaid work.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The Dutch-born woman ordinarily stays in Harlesden, north-west London, but is currently living in Amsterdam with friends, meaning she would have to return to the UK every weekend.

Mr Quinton said: ‘The defendant’s understanding of an overnight coach to the UK every weekend to do the hours was that she does not need to spend any money other than the £8 coach fare – there seems to be a lack of understanding of the practicalities.

‘The court needs to understand that it is dealing with somebody with a traumatic brain injury.’

Reading Crown Court heard how Peereboom refused to talk with her lawyer (Picture: Google)

Adjourning sentence, Judge Sarah Campbell told Peereboom: ‘I feel I am left with not many options.

‘You are 23 years of age and you were found guilty of assault by beating and causing actual bodily harm while on a busy train, which in my view, was deeply unpleasant and animalistic.

‘Your sarcastic demeanour could be seen on the CCTV footage as you pulled a victim’s hair hard and removed it from her head in clumps.

‘What ensued can only be described as a scrum and you lost control of yourself.

‘Ms Marabet was trying to get past you when her leg was bitten causing a permanent scar and needing tetanus jabs.’

The judge said she would consider a previous warning to Peereboom in 2011 for biting a police officer when she was 15, and her difficult upbringing, having been put in care at the age of 14.

Judge Campbell also said there could be exceptional circumstances to defer sentencing for two months to allow Peereboom to either to find a place to live in the UK or get a job to pay compensation.

Advertisement

Peereboom listed as an actress, model, dancer and choreographer on online talent agency platform StarNow, where she states she is an ‘outgoing person who loves fashion, keeping fit and doing her makeup’.

The Internet Movie Database carries no listing for Peereboom.
